required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Scapular Muscle Endurance, Shoulder Pain, and Functionality
clinical_study.official_title: Scapular Muscle Endurance, Shoulder Pain, and Functionality in Patients With Rotator Cuff Lesions: A Prospective Case-Control Study

brief_summary.textblock: Rotator cuff lesions (RCL) are one of the most common shoulder joint disorders. The most important cause of RCL is the impairment of the balance of synergies and force couples of muscles responsible for scapulothoracic stabilization.This study aims to compare SME, shoulder pain, and functionality of patients with rotator cuff lesions (RCL) with those in the matched healthy controls and to evaluate the relationship between SME with shoulder pain, and functional impairments in patients with RCL.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS) (n:20), and partial rotator cuff tears (PRCT) (n:20), and age-gender matched healthy controls (n:20) were included in the study. SME were measured by a one-kilogram dynamometer while the shoulder and elbows are flexed 90°. Self-reported pain intensity (during rest, activity, night, and measurement pain) was assessed visual analog scale (VAS). Functionality was also assessed using the Functional Impairment test-hand, neck, shoulder, and arm (FIT-HaNSA).

arm_group.description: Participants were assessed for SME, pain (rest, activity, night, measurement), shoulder girdle and scapular muscle strengths and upper extremity function (FIT-HaNSA).
Participants were assessed for SME, pain (rest, activity, night, measurement), shoulder girdle and scapular muscle strengths and upper extremity function (FIT-HaNSA).
Participants were assessed for SME, shoulder girdle and scapular muscle strengths and upper extremity function (FIT-HaNSA).

intervention.description: The SME test, developed by Edmondston et al. 17, is based on an exercise used to improve the performance of the serratus anterior and trapezius muscles. The test was carried out while the subjects were facing the wall in standing position and with their shoulders and elbows flexed to 90 degrees. While both scapulae were in neutral position, an appropriate size of stick (18-36 cm) was selected and placed between the elbows, and they were asked to hold the dynamometer (Feta 137 F0202 1 kg/10 N) between their hands.

Pain intensity assessment was performed by questioning rest, activity, night, and measuremant pain using a visual analogue scale (VAS) on a 10 cm line with marks at both ends to define the limits of the pain experience as "no pain" (0) and "maximum pain experienced" (10), with higher scores indicating greater pain 20.

The Functional Impairment Test-Hand and Neck/Shoulder/Arm (FIT-HaNSA) protocol, which was developed by MacDermid et al. 21, was used to evaluate the functional performance of the upper extremity when performing 3 tasks.

study_pop.textblock: Fourty patients and 20 age-gender matched healthy subjects who met the inclusion criteria were included to the study

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Positive sign in two or more specific shoulder clinical tests;
- Presence of RCL (subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS) or PRCT) in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
- At least 120° flexion, 30° abduction and 30° external rotation movements of the shoulder;
- The dominant arm that all the individuals who involved in the study use is the right one;
- No surgical history in the shoulder region,
- No history of physiotherapy in the shoulder region in the previous 3 months.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with a neurological and systemic inflammatory diseases,
- bilateral shoulder complaints, neck pain, and fracture history in the shoulder region, and patients with a frozen shoulder, full-thickness rotator cuff tear on MRI,
- cardiovascular system diseases,
- pregnant women were excluded.
